title: How does the salivary gland get blocked? - Quora

response.answer_text: This condition is called sialolithiasis, from the roots sialo- = saliva + lith = stone + iasis = condition. It’s certainly an apt name. Here’s a photo of one in position (in situ) and four “salivary stones” removed from a patient.  These stones occur more often in the submandibular gland below the tongue than in the parotid salivary gland in front of the ear. The cause is usually unknown, but you can read here on what are thought to be some causes and why they occur most often in the submandibular gland. This also covers symptoms and treatments, including some possible ways of getting rid of them yourself if they aren’t too large. Sialolithiasis - Wikipedia
